Award.AwardTitle: Quantitative Analysis of Metabolic Networks and Flux Dynamics in Thermophilic Bacteria

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Thermus thermophilus is a potential host bacterium for the production of biofuels and other useful biochemicals. However, relatively little is known about its metabolism and the regulation of its metabolic activity. This project will characterize the metabolic network of this organism and quantify its metabolic flux phenotypes using classical steady-state techniques. In addition, techniques will be developed for dynamic metabolic flux analysis and metabolic network elucidation, requiring new tools and methods based on 13C-isotopomer analysis and tandem mass spectrometry. This project will 1) develop a new method of dynamic metabolic flux analysis, 2) provide improved techniques for validating metabolic network models, and 3) define optimized growth conditions for T. thermophilus.

Broader Impacts: This project promises a major step forward in metabolic network analysis that will be broadly applicable to many organisms of biotechnological and biomedical importance. In addition, this project provides unique opportunities for graduate and undergraduate student education and training in an interdisciplinary environment comprising computational and experimental biology, metabolic flux analysis, mass spectrometry and metabolic network modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Thermophilic organisms are increasingly considered for a variety of synthetic biology applications. In theory, high growth temperatures can promote higher rates of feedstock conversion, reduce cooling costs in fermentations, facilitate the removal and recovery of products, and decrease chances of contamination. Moreover, many thermophiles readily ferment pentoses and hexoses, and even, in some cases, polymeric precursors and structurally complex polycarbohydrates such as cellulose and hemicellulose, an important characteristic for the development of next generation biofuel processes. However, compared to mesophilic organisms, relatively little is known about the metabolism thermophilic organisms. This lack of basic understanding is limiting our ability to rationally engineer thermophiles for practical applications in biotechnology.

Intellectual merit. The objective of this project was to elucidate the metabolism of a wide range of thermophilic organisms using state-of-the-art techniques for 13C-metabolic flux analysis and dynamic metabolic flux analysis. We have successfully completed metabolic reconstructions for several evolutionarily divergent thermophilic organisms, including Thermus, Rhodothermus, Geobacillus, and Sulfolobus. For several of these organisms, no reference genome sequences were available, thus we sequenced the genomes of these organisms and reconstructed genome-scale models. Further, to demonstrate the biotechnological potential of thermophiles in general, we evolved one of the strains (Thermus thermophilus) to efficiently co-utilize glucose and xylose without carbon catabolite repression. Additionally, we isolated a new fast-growing Geobacillus strain which has the highest known glucose and xylose conversion capacity of any reported organism to date.

An important second objective of this project was to develop novel metabolic flux analysis tools and techniques to quantify complex dynamics in microbial cell cultures. Thus far, flux analysis techniques have been limited to analysis of steady-state systems, which are uncommon in practice. In this project we developed novel algorithms and tools for dynamic metabolic flux analysis (DMFA). These tools were then subsequently applied to investigate metabolism in dynamic fed-batch fermentations and complex co-culture systems where multiple microbial organisms grow together and exchange metabolites.

Broader impact. In recent years, there has been a significant interest in understanding how microbes interact with each other and how these interactions impact the global behavior of microbial communities. The tools we have developed in this project for dynamic flux analysis and analysis of complex co-cultures are ideally suited to address these questions. As such, the outcomes of in this project are enabling fundamental research on microbiomes that we are now undertaking.
